content.webTitle: Andy Murray tells tennis to get tough and ban the cheats

fields.headline: Andy Murray tells tennis to get tough and ban the cheats
fields.bodyText: If there are any alleged match-fixing cheats lurking still in the men’s draw of the 2016 Australian Open, Andy Murray is unaware of either their names or the measure of their guilt. But he is sure of one thing : he wants genuine offenders found and punished. All inquiries after Murray’s straight sets victory over 18-year-old Alexander Zverev in the first round here on Tuesday were trained on the topic that has spread through the tournament like a virus for two days: allegations by the BBC and BuzzFeed that eight players in the draw had been suspected in the past of involvement in match-fixing. The world No2 described match-fixing as a “massive problem” and called for anyone found guilty of the offence to be banned. He also questioned how right it was for betting companies to sponsor tournaments, with the BBC-BuzzFeed allegations bringing scrutiny on the Australian Open’s partnership with William Hill. He described it as “a little bit hypocritical” and called for the tennis authorities to do more in terms of education and transparency. The unnamed offenders are said to include a grand slam champion, although there has been no indication of who it might be or if the athlete is even still playing, and there is resentment in the higher circles of tennis administration that these claims have not only taken the gloss off the first slam tournament of the season, but the initial story did not produce names or concrete proof of illegal behaviour. The counter argument is that they have been timid in their pursuit of transgressors for fear of losing sponsors. Murray sees both sides of the argument. For years he has been unforgiving in his condemnation of past offenders and classes the use of performance-enhancing drugs alongside tanking as crimes which can only leave a deep bruise on the sport’s image. “Both are massive concerns to any sport,” said Murray following his 6-1, 6-2, 6-3 win against German Zverev. “You don’t want that to go on. But it does. No sports are clean of doping and none are clean of fixing. And it’s not just sport. That’s, like, life in general. People cheat. A lot of people cheat in other jobs as well. People do it in relationships as well. “It’s just that, when it does happen, you want people to be prosecuted, you want them to be banned and you want them to be found out. I, as a player, can’t ban people. It’s up to the authorities to do something about it. And you just want to make sure that they are.” Warming to the theme of retribution, Murray said he could not judge whether the game’s administrators are shying away from hunting down offenders or not – as is alleged in the BBC-BuzzFeed investigation – but he added: “Stories like this, although they’re tough for sports, it does force them to react, maybe do more about it, invest more in the Tennis Integrity Unit and doping programmes. Although [administrators] don’t necessarily want to hear about tennis or their own sport being involved in anything like this, it can be positive in some ways, as well, if they react properly. “The thing is, prosecuting and having the right evidence to be able to do that … I’m sure the betting companies are pretty aware of everything that’s going on. They know when they see something that’s not quite right. Having enough evidence to prosecute – from what I’ve been told – is very difficult. But I don’t think that they would be lying for the sake of it. I think they know when something’s not quite right.” While Murray acknowledges betting companies’ role in providing information on suspicious betting patterns, he clearly feels the role they play as tournament sponsors does not sit well with the rules and responsibilities of global tennis. “I think it’s a little bit hypocritical,” he said. “I’m not really pro that, I don’t think. I don’t believe the players are allowed to be sponsored by betting companies but then the tournaments are. I don’t really understand how it all works. I think it’s a bit strange.” He added: “I do think it’s important that, from a younger age, players are better educated and are made more aware of what they should do in those situations and how a decision like that can affect your career, can affect the whole sport. I think you should be learning about those things from 15, 16, 17 years old and being warned about it.” Speaking before Fernando Verdasco’s shock defeat of Rafael Nadal, whom Murray was scheduled to meet in the semi-finals, he declared himself satisfied with his performance against Zverev. But he acknowledged that Sam Groth, whom he and Jamie Murray beat when the big server combined with Lleyton Hewitt in the doubles of the Davis Cup semi-finals in Glasgow last year, will be a far tougher opponent in Thursday’s second round match. Groth had a playful dig after beating the Frenchman Adrian Mannarino, hoping Murray would honour his pledge to abandon the tournament the moment he learns his wife, Kim, is about to give birth to their first child. “It would be nice if his wife went into labour overnight!” Groth said. “I might be just cheering for that one. But, no, no, I’ve got nothing to lose. He’s going to be tough. He’s a quality player. He’s where he is for a reason. Hopefully I will serve well and it doesn’t come back. I’m going to take it to him.” Murray revealed he has been on edge waiting for news from London about the impending birth. “It’s been a long time since she has not been with me at a slam. This morning I ordered room service and I got a phone call to my room that woke me up – and I completely panicked. I answered the phone and they were, like: ‘We’re just at your door with the room service.’ I just couldn’t hear them knocking at the door.” He will have no such trouble hearing Groth’s thunderbolts on Thursday.
